answers.answer: Risk factors include:HypertensionDiabetesCigarette smokingMore than 2 alcoholic drinks per day.Falling or other trauma to the head.Congenital arteriovenous malformation (AVM) ruptures. AVM is an abnormal tangle of thin-walled blood vessels that is present at birth.If you can afford to have a brain MRI and a doctor will order it, that's fine, but avoid CT scan unless absolutely necessary as it delivers a large dose of radiation.

I agree 100% with Caryopteris and will add that, yes, I do believe hereditary factors can play a role.Under normal circumstances, without any clear evidence for a cerebrovascular abnormality, there is no way that I personally would be willing to undergo a cerebral CT scan, for the exact reason Caryopteris stated.  What I would do is to live a healthy lifestyle and avoid the avoidable risk factors.
